prompt: Procedures: CPT 31646, 31641. DX J98.09. Patient 35 M. Findings: Organized clot in RUL, exchange of bronchial blocker. Cryotherapy utilized.
completion:
NOTE_ID:  note_010 SOURCE_FILE: note_010.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT 

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] 

INDICATION FOR OPERATION  [REDACTED] is a 35-year-old male who presents with recurrent hemoptysis.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained. 

CONSENT  Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
The patient or surrogate read and signed the provided consent form or provided consent over the phone.
The consent was witnessed by an assisting medical professional. 

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS 
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS 
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE 
Therapeutic aspiration (subsequent episodes) (CPT 31646) 
Destruction of tumor or relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (e.g., laser therapy, cryotherapy) (CPT 31641) 

ANESTHESIA  Moderate sedation (CPT 99152).
Medications: Versed 8 mg; Fentanyl 100 mcg.

Time: Start 1450; Stop 1510 (Total 20 minutes).
Assessment: The patient was monitored continuously one-to-one throughout the entire procedure by the attending physician while anesthesia was administered.
MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION  Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope; Cryoprobe system; Uniblocker. 

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality.
Patient Position: Supine 

Initial Airway Inspection: 

Tracheostomy: The tracheostomy tube was in good position.
Pharynx/Larynx/Vocal Cords: Not assessed due to bronchoscopy introduction through tracheostomy tube.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal.

Main Carina: Sharp.
Left Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. Thin rusty secretions were noted.
Minor mucosal thickening noted in LB1/2.

Right Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level mostly.
However, an endobronchial balloon was noted at the RUL/Apical Segment with organized clot obscuring evaluation of distal airways.
A 9Fr Arndt blocker was noted in the middle of the right mainstem (RMS); the balloon was deflated.

Mucosa: Normal.
Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear (aside from specific areas noted).
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, Carina, LUL Carina (Lc1), LLL Carina (LC2), RUL Carina (RC1), and RML Carina (RC2) from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Endobronchial Blocker Placement A 7Fr Uniblocker balloon occlusion was performed at the Right Carina (RC1) and secured in place with the Uniblocker ventilator adaptor.
Placement: At the tape level at dark blue securement device.
Inflation: Confirmed that 3 cc of air was required to inflate the balloon to fully occlude the RUL.
The endobronchial blocker balloon was intermittently inflated in the RUL to assist with clot removal.

Cryo-Extraction of Mucus Casts/Secretions A 1.9 mm cryoprobe was applied to adherent organized clot at the RUL/Apical Segment.
Technique: 5–10 second freeze cycles. 

Result: Excellent clot removal. The airway was cleared with improved ventilation.

Hemostasis and Conclusion After the organized clot was removed from the RUL orifice, the blocker balloon was deflated.
No blood was noted coming from RB1, RB2 or RB3. The blocker was left deflated.
The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications. 

SPECIMENS  None

IMPRESSION / PLAN 
[REDACTED] is a 35-year-old male who presented for bronchoscopy for evaluation of recurrent hemoptysis.
Cryotherapy (cryoprobe) successfully used to evacuate the RUL airways of organized clot.
7Fr Uniblocker was placed and left deflated at the RUL.
The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications. 

PRN bronchoscopy as needed.
Decannulation as appropriate.

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] 

INDICATION FOR OPERATION  [REDACTED] is a 49-year-old female who presents with massive hemoptysis.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained. 

CONSENT  Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
The patient or surrogate read and signed the provided consent form or provided consent over the phone.
The consent was witnessed by an assisting medical professional. 

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS 
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS 
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE 
Therapeutic aspiration (subsequent episodes) (CPT 31646) 
Destruction of tumor or relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (e.g., laser therapy, cryotherapy) (CPT 31641) 

ANESTHESIA  Moderate sedation (CPT 99152).
Medications: Versed 10 mg; Fentanyl 150 mcg.

Time: Start 1450; Stop 1510 (Total 20 minutes).
Assessment: The patient was monitored continuously one-to-one throughout the entire procedure by the attending physician while anesthesia was administered.
MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION  Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope; Cryoprobe system; Uniblocker. 

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality.
Patient Position: Supine 

Initial Airway Inspection: 

Tracheostomy: The tracheostomy tube was in good position.
Pharynx/Larynx/Vocal Cords: Not assessed due to bronchoscopy introduction through tracheostomy tube.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal.

Main Carina: Sharp.
Left Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. Thin rusty secretions were noted.
Minor mucosal thickening noted in LB1/2.

Right Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level mostly.
However, an endobronchial balloon was noted at the RUL/Apical Segment with organized clot obscuring evaluation of distal airways.
A 7Fr Arndt blocker was noted in the middle of the right mainstem (RMS); the balloon was deflated.

Mucosa: Normal.
Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear (aside from specific areas noted).
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, Carina, LUL Carina (Lc1), LLL Carina (LC2), RUL Carina (RC1), and RML Carina (RC2) from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Endobronchial Blocker Placement A 7Fr Uniblocker balloon occlusion was performed at the Right Carina (RC1) and secured in place with the Uniblocker ventilator adaptor.
Placement: At the tape level at dark blue securement device.
Inflation: Confirmed that 3 cc of air was required to inflate the balloon to fully occlude the RUL.
The endobronchial blocker balloon was intermittently inflated in the RUL to assist with clot removal.

Cryo-Extraction of Mucus Casts/Secretions A 1.1 mm cryoprobe was applied to adherent organized clot at the RUL/Apical Segment.
Technique: 5–10 second freeze cycles. 

Result: Excellent clot removal. The airway was cleared with improved ventilation.

Hemostasis and Conclusion After the organized clot was removed from the RUL orifice, the blocker balloon was deflated.
No blood was noted coming from RB1, RB2 or RB3. The blocker was left deflated.
The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications. 

SPECIMENS  None

IMPRESSION / PLAN

PRN bronchoscopy as needed.

Right Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. Thin rusty secretions were noted.
Cavity was noted in the RB2 subsegment and entered.

Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear (aside from specific areas noted).

The endobronchial blocker balloon was intermittently inflated in the LUL to assist with clot removal.

Cryo-Extraction of Mucus Casts/Secretions A 1.9 mm cryoprobe was applied to adherent organized clot at the lingula/LUL.

Hemostasis and Conclusion After the organized clot was removed from the LUL orifice, the blocker balloon was deflated.
No blood was noted coming from LB1/2 or LB3. The blocker was left deflated.
The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained. 

CONSENT  Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
The patient or surrogate read and signed the provided consent form or provided consent over the phone.
The consent was witnessed by an assisting medical professional. 

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS 
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS 
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE 
Therapeutic aspiration (subsequent episodes) (CPT 31646) 
Destruction of tumor or relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (e.g., laser therapy, cryotherapy) (CPT 31641) 

ANESTHESIA  Moderate sedation (CPT 99152).
Medications: Propofol 100 mg; Fentanyl 50 mcg.

Time: Start 1450; Stop 1510 (Total 20 minutes).
Assessment: The patient was monitored continuously one-to-one throughout the entire procedure by the attending physician while anesthesia was administered.
MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION  Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope; Cryoprobe system; Uniblocker. 

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality.
Patient Position: Supine 

Initial Airway Inspection: 

Tracheostomy: The tracheostomy tube was in good position.
Pharynx/Larynx/Vocal Cords: Not assessed due to bronchoscopy introduction through tracheostomy tube.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal.

Main Carina: Sharp.
Right Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. Thin rusty secretions were noted.
Cavity was noted in the RB2 subsegment and entered.

Left Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level mostly.
However, an endobronchial balloon was noted at the lingula/LUL with organized clot obscuring evaluation of distal airways.
A 9Fr Arndt blocker was noted in the middle of the left mainstem (LMS); the balloon was deflated.

Mucosa: Normal.
Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear (aside from specific areas noted).
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Left Mainstem, Carina, RUL Carina (RC1), RML Carina (RC2), LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1), and Left Carina (LC2) from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Endobronchial Blocker Placement A 7Fr Uniblocker balloon occlusion was performed at the Left Carina (LC2) and secured in place with the Uniblocker ventilator adaptor.
Placement: At the tape level at dark blue securement device.
Inflation: Confirmed that 3 cc of air was required to inflate the balloon to fully occlude the LUL.
The endobronchial blocker balloon was intermittently inflated in the LUL to assist with clot removal.

Cryo-Extraction of Mucus Casts/Secretions A 1.9 mm cryoprobe was applied to adherent organized clot at the lingula/LUL.
Technique: 5–10 second freeze cycles. 

Result: Excellent clot removal. The airway was cleared with improved ventilation.

Hemostasis and Conclusion After the organized clot was removed from the LUL orifice, the blocker balloon was deflated.
No blood was noted coming from LB1/2 or LB3. The blocker was left deflated.
The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications. 

SPECIMENS  None

IMPRESSION / PLAN 
[REDACTED] is a 49-year-old male who presented for bronchoscopy for evaluation of hemoptysis.
Cryotherapy (cryoprobe) successfully used to evacuate the LUL airways of organized clot.
7Fr Uniblocker was placed and left deflated at the LUL.
The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications. 

PRN bronchoscopy as needed.
Decannulation as appropriate.

NOTE_ID:  note_010 SOURCE_FILE: note_010.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT 

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] 

INDICATION FOR OPERATION  [REDACTED] is a 35-year-old female who presents with recurrent hemoptysis.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained. 

CONSENT  Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
The patient or surrogate read and signed the provided consent form or provided consent over the phone.
The consent was witnessed by an assisting medical professional. 

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS 
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS 
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE 
Therapeutic aspiration (subsequent episodes) (CPT 31646) 
Destruction of tumor or relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (e.g., laser therapy, cryotherapy) (CPT 31641) 

ANESTHESIA  Moderate sedation (CPT 99152).
Medications: Propofol 100 mg; Fentanyl 50 mcg.

Time: Start 1450; Stop 1510 (Total 20 minutes).
Assessment: The patient was monitored continuously one-to-one throughout the entire procedure by the attending physician while anesthesia was administered.
MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION  Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope; Cryoprobe system; Uniblocker. 

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality.
Patient Position: Supine 

Initial Airway Inspection: 

Tracheostomy: The tracheostomy tube was in good position.
Pharynx/Larynx/Vocal Cords: Not assessed due to bronchoscopy introduction through tracheostomy tube.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal.

Main Carina: Sharp.
Right Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. Thin rusty secretions were noted.
Cavity was noted in the RB2 subsegment and entered.

Left Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level mostly.
However, an endobronchial balloon was noted at the lingula/LUL with organized clot obscuring evaluation of distal airways.
A 7Fr Arndt blocker was noted in the middle of the left mainstem (LMS); the balloon was deflated.

Mucosa: Normal.
Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear (aside from specific areas noted).
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Left Mainstem, Carina, RUL Carina (RC1), RML Carina (RC2), LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1), and Left Carina (LC2) from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Endobronchial Blocker Placement A 7Fr Uniblocker balloon occlusion was performed at the Left Carina (LC2) and secured in place with the Uniblocker ventilator adaptor.
Placement: At the tape level at dark blue securement device.
Inflation: Confirmed that 3 cc of air was required to inflate the balloon to fully occlude the LUL.
The endobronchial blocker balloon was intermittently inflated in the LUL to assist with clot removal.

Cryo-Extraction of Mucus Casts/Secretions A 1.1 mm cryoprobe was applied to adherent organized clot at the lingula/LUL.
Technique: 5–10 second freeze cycles. 

Result: Excellent clot removal. The airway was cleared with improved ventilation.

Hemostasis and Conclusion After the organized clot was removed from the LUL orifice, the blocker balloon was deflated.
No blood was noted coming from LB1/2 or LB3. The blocker was left deflated.
The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications. 

SPECIMENS  None

IMPRESSION / PLAN 
[REDACTED] is a 35-year-old female who presented for bronchoscopy for evaluation of recurrent hemoptysis.
Cryotherapy (cryoprobe) successfully used to evacuate the LUL airways of organized clot.
7Fr Uniblocker was placed and left deflated at the LUL.
The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications. 

PRN bronchoscopy as needed.
Decannulation as appropriate.

INDICATION FOR OPERATION  [REDACTED] is a 24-year-old female who presents with massive hemoptysis.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained. 

CONSENT  Obtained before the procedure.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS 
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE 
Therapeutic aspiration (subsequent episodes) (CPT 31646) 
Destruction of tumor or relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (e.g., laser therapy, cryotherapy) (CPT 31641) 

ANESTHESIA  Moderate sedation (CPT 99152).
Medications: Versed 6 mg; Fentanyl 75 mcg.

Time: Start 1450; Stop 1510 (Total 20 minutes).
Assessment: The patient was monitored continuously one-to-one throughout the entire procedure by the attending physician while anesthesia was administered.
MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION  Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope; Cryoprobe system; Uniblocker. 

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality.
Patient Position: Supine 

Initial Airway Inspection: 

Tracheostomy: The tracheostomy tube was in good position.
Pharynx/Larynx/Vocal Cords: Not assessed due to bronchoscopy introduction through tracheostomy tube.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal.

Main Carina: Sharp.
Right Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. Thin rusty secretions were noted.
Cavity was noted in the RB2 subsegment and entered.

Left Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level mostly.
However, an endobronchial balloon was noted at the lingula/LUL with organized clot obscuring evaluation of distal airways.
A 9Fr Arndt blocker was noted in the middle of the left mainstem (LMS); the balloon was deflated.

Mucosa: Normal.
Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear (aside from specific areas noted).
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Left Mainstem, Carina, RUL Carina (RC1), RML Carina (RC2), LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1), and Left Carina (LC2) from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Endobronchial Blocker Placement A 7Fr Uniblocker balloon occlusion was performed at the Left Carina (LC2) and secured in place with the Uniblocker ventilator adaptor.
Placement: At the tape level at dark blue securement device.
Inflation: Confirmed that 3 cc of air was required to inflate the balloon to fully occlude the LUL.
The endobronchial blocker balloon was intermittently inflated in the LUL to assist with clot removal.

Cryo-Extraction of Mucus Casts/Secretions A 2.4 mm cryoprobe was applied to adherent organized clot at the lingula/LUL.
Technique: 5–10 second freeze cycles. 

Result: Excellent clot removal. The airway was cleared with improved ventilation.

Hemostasis and Conclusion After the organized clot was removed from the LUL orifice, the blocker balloon was deflated.
No blood was noted coming from LB1/2 or LB3. The blocker was left deflated.
The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications. 

SPECIMENS  None

Left Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. Thin rusty secretions were noted.
Minor mucosal thickening noted in LB1/2.

Right Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level mostly.
However, an endobronchial balloon was noted at the RUL/Apical Segment with organized clot obscuring evaluation of distal airways.
A 7Fr Arndt blocker was noted in the middle of the right mainstem (RMS); the balloon was deflated.

Mucosa: Normal.
Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear (aside from specific areas noted).
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, Carina, LUL Carina (Lc1), LLL Carina (LC2), RUL Carina (RC1), and RML Carina (RC2) from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Endobronchial Blocker Placement A 9Fr Uniblocker balloon occlusion was performed at the Right Carina (RC1) and secured in place with the Uniblocker ventilator adaptor.
Placement: At the tape level at dark blue securement device.
Inflation: Confirmed that 3 cc of air was required to inflate the balloon to fully occlude the RUL.
The endobronchial blocker balloon was intermittently inflated in the RUL to assist with clot removal.

Cryo-Extraction of Mucus Casts/Secretions A 1.1 mm cryoprobe was applied to adherent organized clot at the RUL/Apical Segment.
Technique: 5–10 second freeze cycles. 

Result: Excellent clot removal. The airway was cleared with improved ventilation.

Hemostasis and Conclusion After the organized clot was removed from the RUL orifice, the blocker balloon was deflated.
No blood was noted coming from RB1, RB2 or RB3. The blocker was left deflated.
The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications. 

SPECIMENS  None

IMPRESSION / PLAN

Cryotherapy (cryoprobe) successfully used to evacuate the RUL airways of organized clot.
9Fr Uniblocker was placed and left deflated at the RUL.
The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications. 

PRN bronchoscopy as needed.
Decannulation as appropriate.

INSTRUMENTATION  Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope; Cryoprobe system; Uniblocker.

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality.
Patient Position: Supine 

Initial Airway Inspection: 

Tracheostomy: The tracheostomy tube was in good position.
Pharynx/Larynx/Vocal Cords: Not assessed due to bronchoscopy introduction through tracheostomy tube.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal.

Main Carina: Sharp.
Left Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. Thin rusty secretions were noted.
Minor mucosal thickening noted in LB1/2.

Right Lung: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level mostly.
However, an endobronchial balloon was noted at the RUL/Apical Segment with organized clot obscuring evaluation of distal airways.
A 9Fr Arndt blocker was noted in the middle of the right mainstem (RMS); the balloon was deflated.

Mucosa: Normal.
Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear (aside from specific areas noted).
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, Carina, LUL Carina (Lc1), LLL Carina (LC2), RUL Carina (RC1), and RML Carina (RC2) from mucus, blood, and blood clots.

Endobronchial Blocker Placement A 9Fr Uniblocker balloon occlusion was performed at the Right Carina (RC1) and secured in place with the Uniblocker ventilator adaptor.
Placement: At the tape level at dark blue securement device.
Inflation: Confirmed that 3 cc of air was required to inflate the balloon to fully occlude the RUL.
The endobronchial blocker balloon was intermittently inflated in the RUL to assist with clot removal.

Cryo-Extraction of Mucus Casts/Secretions A 1.9 mm cryoprobe was applied to adherent organized clot at the RUL/Apical Segment.
Technique: 5–10 second freeze cycles. 

Result: Excellent clot removal. The airway was cleared with improved ventilation.

Hemostasis and Conclusion After the organized clot was removed from the RUL orifice, the blocker balloon was deflated.
No blood was noted coming from RB1, RB2 or RB3. The blocker was left deflated.
The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications. 

SPECIMENS  None

Cryotherapy (cryoprobe) successfully used to evacuate the RUL airways of organized clot.
9Fr Uniblocker was placed and left deflated at the RUL.
The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications. 

PRN bronchoscopy as needed.
Decannulation as appropriate.
